Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story: I sat at my workbench, the hum of the factory quieter than usual during this slow season. My phone buzzed with messages from my daughter, reminders about the upcoming family holiday. It’s tradition—everyone gathers, stories are shared, and I’m expected to be there, present and attentive, the glue that keeps us connected. But just as I was about to reply, a supervisor rushed in, worry etched on his face. The old packaging machine, the one we barely use, was acting up again—intermittent glitches, nothing obvious, but enough to threaten the next week’s orders. They needed me, the only one who really understood its quirks, to diagnose and fix it before things picked up. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in: my family expecting warmth and presence, my team relying on my expertise to keep the line running. My heart tugged in two directions, torn between the comfort of home and the responsibility of work, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed at the same time.
